description: Hierarchical clustering is an unsupervised learning technique used to group similar objects into clusters based on their characteristics. It creates a hierarchy of clusters by either a bottom-up (agglomerative) or top-down (divisive) approach, resulting in a tree-like structure called a dendrogram.

common_types.name: Agglomerative Clustering
common_types.description: A bottom-up approach that starts with individual data points as clusters and iteratively merges the closest pairs of clusters until a single cluster is formed or a specified number of clusters is reached.

common_types.name: Divisive Clustering
common_types.description: A top-down approach that begins with a single cluster containing all data points and recursively splits it into smaller clusters until each data point forms its own cluster or a desired number of clusters is achieved.

common_types.name: Complete Linkage Clustering
common_types.description: A method that considers the maximum distance between points in different clusters, leading to more compact clusters with smaller diameters.

common_types.name: Single Linkage Clustering
common_types.description: A method that considers the minimum distance between points in different clusters, which can result in elongated, chain-like clusters.

visualization_techniques.description: A tree-like diagram that illustrates the arrangement of clusters, showing the relationships between clusters and how they are merged or split.
A graphical representation of data where individual values are represented as colors, often used in conjunction with hierarchical clustering to visualize the structure of clusters.
Displays the clustered data points in a two-dimensional or three-dimensional space, allowing for a visual assessment of cluster formation.
Visualizes how close each data point in one cluster is to points in the neighboring clusters, providing insight into the appropriateness of the clustering.

applications: Biological taxonomy to classify organisms based on genetic information.
Market segmentation to identify distinct customer groups.
Document clustering for organizing and summarizing large text datasets.
Image analysis for grouping similar images or features in computer vision.
